And technically no physical information can travel faster than light, but gravity isn't information, and gravity can warp speed.
Technically waves can have mass as long as there frequency and wavelength don't multiply to numbers passed 186,000 miles per second.
And particles don't have amplitude or peaks (crests and troughs), wavelength, or repeating cycles.
Waves don't have spin, unless there carried by the EM force.
Fermions such as quarks and leptons have a 1/2 integer spin, unlike bosons, which have a derivative spin.
Angular momentum is when you position your moving mass on an x, y and z axis.
A wave is when gravity stretches and contracts travelling information. A particle is when gravity holds information still and considers angular momentum.
Waves actually behave the way they do becauee they are being bent do to gravity. Gravity can attract, orbit, spin, loop, and amplify.
I think there is small error in one of the slides at 4:58. The intensity becomes proportional to 1/r^4 and not 1/r^2.

The animation at 2:02 has a fault. The intention is to show the difference in travel speed in different mediums. The blue waveform has to travel faster as the pink one. +Gigabyte22 yeah I'm doing OCR A level physics at the moment, so I know that a lot of this definitely comes up (I've just finished my first year), but I was more interested in this whole course on crash course I.e. Which episodes do I not need to watch

It can sometimes be a problem. But it's one with an easy fix. When you listen to a video on a new topic, click on the frame so it gets focus, and then keep your hand hovered over the spacebar. When they say a thought that is new to you, hit the pause button and take a moment to digest; or go back to repeat if needed.   So like, for CC Chemistry, I was pausing the thing pretty constantly. For this one, since transferring colleges made me retake tons of intro physics, I can pretty much just play it in the background and follow along.  The great thing about removing all the pauses is than when you've become more comfortable with the topic, you can review the information very quickly and efficiently allowing you to figure out which portions you haven't completely absorbed.

Atlas Enderium Precisely, no one ever attempts to explain anything beyond the elementary schoolbook understanding. I'd really appreciate someone...anyone, that would give a more up to date examination of exactly how photons travel, in various frequencies and intensities, at the same speed through a vacuum maintaining a wave form functionality. All these freshman physics level videos only address the same rhetoric and stop at the 'we don't know' point. Everyone has the basic wave function understanding having taken physics 101 - I'd really like to hear something a little more advanced and even speculative on what we know now given recent LHC discoveries - not the same basics over and over from 1930. +Nexus2Eden in a classical sense electromagnetic waves "wave" because a changing electric field makes a magnetic field, and a changing magnetic field makes an electric field. So if the right conditions are met you will get an electric and magnetic field to change themselves in the right way to make this work in a wave that travels through space. As for a quantum explanation... IDK sorry.

Explaining how light travels without a medium most certainly does not need to bring in any quantum mechanics at all.  There is nothing speculative about it and it most certainly is not something investigated by the LHC. You don't need physics anywhere near as advanced as in the 1930s, let alone later. Light is an electromagnetic wave. What this means is essentially there is a waving magnetic field, and a waving electric field.   A changing electric field, causes a changing magnetic field and vice versa. So if you bounce an electron up and down, this causes a changing electric field, as the charged electron essentially 'drags' (for way of an analogy, if you want it properly look up maxwell's equations) the electric field with it. So as you bounce the electron, the electric field waves with it. This changing electric field then causes a changing magnetic field. This changing magnetic field then causes a changing electric field and so on.

Properly explaining the whole wave/particle duality of light is extremely hard. To paraphrase a famous quote: if you think you understand quantum mechanics, then you are almost certainly wrong. A lot of the aspects of the concepts are things that are (so far) best explained via specific experiments, and very long and drawn out mathematical proofs that require a strong grasp of calculus. There are channels that get into this level of detail, but they don't make any sense unless you have all the prerequisites, and they tend to be effectively just recordings of college lectures. They aren't fun and nicely edited and animated with pro lights and sound like these videos because the demand for seriously understanding that stuff is honestly pretty low. Most people who think they are into those sort of concepts seem to prefer the massively dumbed down science-channel version of quantum mechanics; and you're absolutely right, those sort of videos don't explain a damned thing other than some of the conclusions reached; never the "why?".

verdatum Again, you most certainly do not need to go into quantum mechanics to explain why EM waves travel at c. Classical electromagnetism is completely sufficient. Not only do you not need quantum mechanics to do so, you cannot use quantum mechanics to do so. A quantum explanation for the speed of light requires quantum field theory, not quantum mechanics.

Nexus2Eden "Yes, but what is the magnetic field exactly?"  The magnetic field is just the electric field viewed from a position moving relative to it.  "We all understand How the equations work - we don't understand Why they work."  If you understand how maxwell's equations work, you understand why they work. How/why they work is they're essentially the simplest way to keep the laws of physics the same in all reference frames, keep the speed of light constant and treat space the same in all directions.

Nexus2Eden  Yes, this is a waste of time :) Quora is no better than Yahoo Answers for garbage. This response does not support it's claims with any math, experiments, or logical proofs. It is neither published in a reputable journal, nor peer reviewed. I'd go into more specifics, and a younger-me absolutely would have. But it's not worth the effort. "ooo, scientists used to reject quantum field theory in the 70s, therefore I win." No. Scientists raised arguments about the claims at the time related to the concept. This is exactly the same as how scientists first rejected continental drift. They didn't reject it because they were foolish, they rejected it because there were not just unanswered questions, but genuine flaws in the original drift theory. Over time these flaws and unanswered questions may be addressed, and then scientists come to accept the theory as valid. If someone can make a proper incontrovertible argument against quantum field theory, they will have no trouble getting published. That'd be huge. Scientists would love it. However, I'm pretty certain this hasn't happened.
verdatum In addition to all that, even if quantum field theory was completely and utterly wrong ( which clearly, it isn't ), that wouldn't in any way mean that fields are not defined in physics.

Nexus2Eden Awww, come on man. You weren't doing great, but you weren't doing terrible; right until you had to try and personally insult BlueCosmology You didn't even bother to pull up his YouTube channel did you? These are not the sort of videos an 8 year old troll publishes. He is not the one making outrageous claims. You are. And you are not supporting them with anything; no logic, no sources, just evidence of misunderstanding in physics, and the standard distrust of the scientific establishment. Yes, you learn how to describe fields before you learn their causes. That's because that's what scientists did to learn their causes. That's the first step. The cause is the next step, and they aren't the sort of thing you go into via a youtube comment. They are what you learn by taking 400-level and graduate physics courses. And it is stuff that makes no sense without all the prereqs, so, again, you don't get videos on it that are directed at the general audience. I know. It sucks. But it doesn't mean you should start listening to cranks for your answers.

This "4 categories" thing is a little rough. It's more like characteristics. A wave can be a pulse or continuous, and a wave can be transverse or longitudinal. These are ways of describing waves. Gravitational waves can be thought of as falling within this set. Asking "did you forget gravitational waves?" is sort of, but not quite, like asking "did you forget ocean waves?". Also, we only just recently got strong evidence that gravitational waves are a thing. In intro physics, you never have to worry about that bleeding edge until-recently-theoretical stuff (thank goodness!).

transversive waves are like snakes moving, and longituginal waves are like various circles each one inside the other (or you could use the spring example)
For Transverse waves think of it as a string's up and down motion and for Longitudinal think of a Spring expanding and contracting

It's in the names. To traverse = to cross, so transverse are like crossing from one side to the other. Meanwhile, longitudinal goes along with it, the density increases and decreases from the source of the wave and towards its destination.
